And look, he looks as he would kill his hundred
For you sir, were you in danger.

sp.speaker: Allan.
sp.l: Till he kills his brother, his chancellor, then his amster,
To which he can add naught to equal Nero
But killing of his mother.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: Peace, brave fool,
Thou valiant ass, here's his brother too sir,
A captain of your guard hath served you long
With the most noble witness of his truth
Marked in his face, and every part about him
That turns not from an enemies but view him,
And do not grieve him, sir, if you do mean
That he shall hold his place, it is not safe
To tempt such spirits, and let 'em wear their swords,
You make your guards your terrors by these acts,
And throw more hearts off from you than you hold,
And I must tell you sir (With my old freedom,
And my old faith to boot) you have not lived so,
But that your state will need such men, such hands,
Of which here's one shall in an hour of trial
Do you more certain service with a stroke,
Than the whole bundle of your flatterers,
With all th' unsavoury unction of their tongues.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: Peace talker.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: One that loves you yet my lord,
And would not see you pull on your own ruins,
Mercy becomes a prince, and guards him best,
A weaned affrights they are no ties of love,
And when men 'gin to fear the prince, they hate him.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: Am I the prince or you?

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: My lord, I hope
I have not uttered ought should urge that question.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: Then practise your obedience, see him dead.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: I'll hear no word more.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: I am sorry then
There is no small despair sir of their safety,
Whose ears are blocked up against the truth,
Come captain.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I do thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: For what?
For seeing thy brother die a man and honest,
Live thou so captain, I will so, I assure thee,
Although I die for't too. Come. 〈◊〉Exeunt omnes praeter Rollo, and Latorch.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: Now Latorch,
What do you think?

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: That Aubrey's speech and manners
Sound somewhat of the boldest.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: 'Tis his custom.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: It may be so, and yet be worth a fear.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: If we thought so it should be worth his life,
And quickly too.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: I dare not sir be author
Of what I would, he is so dangerous,
But with your highness' favour and your licence.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: He talks 'tis true, and he is licenced: leave him.
We now are Duke alone, Latorch secured,
Nothing left standing to obscure our prospect,
We look right forth, besides and round about us,
And see it ours with pleasure: only one
Wished joy there wants to make us so possess it,
And that is Edith, Edith, she that got me
In blood and tears in such an opposite minute,
As had I not at once felt all the flames,
And shafts of love shot in me (His whole armoury)
I should have thought him as far off as death.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: My lord expect a while, your happiness
Is nearer than you think it, yet her griefs
Are green and fresh, your vigilant Latorch
Hath not been idle, I have leave already
To visit her and send to her.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: My life.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: And if I find not out as speedy ways,
And proper instruments to work and bring her
To your fruition, that she be not watched
Tame to your highness, say you have no servant
Is capable of such a trust about you,
Or worthy to be — of your delight.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: O my Latorch, what shall I render thee
For all thy travels, care, and love?

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Sir, one suit,
Which I will ever importune till you grant me.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: About your mathematicians.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Yes to have
The scheme of your nativity judged by them.
I have't already erected, oh my lord,
You do not know the labour of my fears.
My doubts for you are such as cannot hope
Any security but from the stars,
Who being rightly asked can tell man more,
Than all power else, there being no power beyond them.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: All thy petitions still are care of us.
Ask for thyself.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: What more can concern me
Then this?

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: Well rise true honest man and go then,
We'll study ourselves a means how to reward thee.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Your grace is now inspired, now, now your highness
Begins to live, from this hour count your joys,
But sir, I must have warrants with blank figures
To put in names such as I like.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: You shall.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: They dare not else sir offer at your figure,
Oh I shall bring you wonders, there's a friar,
Russee an admirable man
Another gentleman, and then la Fiske,
The mirror of his time, 'twas he that set it,
But there's one Norbret, (Him I never saw)
Has made a mirror, a mere looking-glass
in show you'd think't no other, the form oval,
As I am given to understand by letter,
Which renders you such shapes, and those so differing
And some that will be questioned, and give answers,
Then has he set it in a frame that wrought
Unto the revolutions of the stars,
And so compacted by due proportions
Unto their harmony doth move alone
A true automicon: thus Dedalus statues
Or Vulcan's stools —

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: Dost thou believe this?

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Sir, why what should stay my faith or turn my sense,
He has been about it above twenty years,
Three sevens, the powerful and the perfect numbers,
And art and time sir can produce such things,
What do we read there, that Hiarba's banquet
The great gymnosophist that had his butlers
And carvers of pure gold wait at the table:
The images of Mercury too, that spoke,
The wooden dove that flew, a snake of brass
That hissed: and birds of silver that did sing.
All these were done sir by the mathematics:
Without which there's no science nor no truth.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: You are in your own sphere (Latorch) and rather
Than I'll contend with you for it, I'll believe you.
Ye have won upon me that I wish to see
My fate before me now, whate'er it be.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: And I'll endeavour you shall know't with speed,
For which I should have one of trust go with me,
If you please, Hamond, that I may by him
Send you my first dispatches: after I
Shall bring you more, as they come more,
And accurate forth from them.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: Take your way,
Choose your own means, and be it prosperous to us.

div.head: Scaena 2.
div.stage: Enter Russe, de Bube, la Fiske, Norbret, Pippeau.

sp.speaker: Russe.
sp.l: Come bear up sirs, we shall have better days,
Mine almanac tells me.

sp.speaker: Bube.
sp.l: What's that, your rump.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: It never itched in vain yet; slid la Fiske,
Throw off thy sluggish face, I cannot abide
To see thee look like a poor jade i'th pound,
That saw no meat these three days.

sp.speaker: Fiske.
sp.l: 'Slight to me,
It seems thirteen days since I saw any.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Fisk.
sp.l: I cannot remember that I ever saw
Or meat or money, you may talk of both,
To open a man's stomach or his purse,
But feed 'em still with air.

sp.speaker: Bube.
sp.l: Friar, I fear
You do not say your office well adays,
I cannot hear your beads knack.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Pox, he feeds
With lechery, and lives upon th'exchange
Of his two eggs and puddings, with the market-women.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: And what do you sir with the advocate's wife,
That you persuade upon your doctoral bed,
To take the mathematical trance so often?

sp.speaker: Fisk●
sp.l: Come we are stark naught all; bad's the best on's,
Four of the seven deadly spots we are,
Besides our lechery we are envious
And most, most gluttonous when we have it thus,
Most covetous now we want it: than our boy,
He is a fifth spot, sloth, and he undoes us.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: 'Tis true the child was wont to be industrious,
And now and then send in a merchant's wife
Sick o'th husband, or a swearing butler
That missed one of his boles; a crying maid
Had lost a silver spoon: the currycomb
sometimes was wanting, there was something gotten
But now —

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: What now, did I not yester-morning
Bring you in a cardecue there from the peasant,
Whose ass I had driven aside and hidden that you
Might conjure for him? and then last night
Six souse from the cook's wife, ye shared among ye
To set a figure for the pestle I stole,
It is not at home yet. These things my masters,
In a hard time they would be thought on, you
Talk o'your lands, and castles in the air
O'your twelve houses there, but it is I
That bring you in your rends for 'em, 'tis Pipeau
That is your bird called.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Faith he does well,
And cuts through the element for us, I must needs say
In a fine dextrous line.

sp.speaker: Fisk.
sp.l: But not as he did
At first, then he would sail with any wind
Int'every creek and corner.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: I was light then,
New built and rigged, when I came to you gentlemen,
But now with often and far venturing for you,
Here be leaks sprung, and whole planks wanting, see you,
If you'll new sheathe me again, yet I am for you
To any bog or sleights, where you'll send me,
For as I am, where can this ragged bark
Put in for any service, less it be
I'th isle of rogues, and there turn pirate for you.

sp.speaker: Norb.
sp.l: Faith he says reason, friar you must leave
Your neat crisped claret, and fall to your cider
A while; and you la Fiske your larded capons
And turkeys for a time, and take a good
Clean tripe in your way; Debube too must content him
With wholesome two soused pettitoes, no more crown ordinaries,
Till we have clothed our infant.

sp.speaker: Bube.
sp.l: So you'll keep your own good motions doctor, your dear self.

sp.speaker: Fiske.
sp.l: Yes for we all do know the latitude
O'your concupiscence.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Here, about your belly.

sp.speaker: Bube.
sp.l: You'll pick a bottle open, or a whimsy
As soon as the best on us.

sp.speaker: Fiske.
sp.l: And dip your wristbands,
(For cuffs you ha' none) as comely in the sauce,Bells ring within.
As any courtier — hark, the bell, who's there. Exit pip. and enter again.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Good luck I do conjure thee, boy look out.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: They are gallants, courtiers, one of 'em is
Of the Duke's bedchamber,

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Latorch down,
On with your gown, there's a new suit arrived
Did I not tell you sons of hunger? Crown's
Crowns are coming towards you: wine and wenches
You shall have once again: and fiddlers
Into your studies close, each lay his ear
This door, and as you hear me to prepare you,
So come, and put me on that visor only.

sp.speaker: Lato.
sp.l: You'll not be far hence captain, when the business
Is done, you shall receive present dispatch.

sp.speaker: Ham●
sp.l: I'll walk sir i'th cloister.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Monsieur Latorch, my son,
The stars are happy still that guide you hither.

sp.speaker: Lator.
sp.l: I am glad to hear their secretary say so,
My learned father Russee, where's la Fiske,
Monsieur la bube, how do they.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: At their studies,
They are the secretaries of the stars sir,
Still at their books, they will not be pulled off,
They stick like cupping glasses; if ever men
Spoke with the tongue of destiny, 'tis they.

sp.speaker: Lator.
sp.l: For love's sake let's salute 'em.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Boy go see,
Tell 'em who's here, say that their friends do challenge
Some portion of their time, this is our minute,
Pray them they will spare it, they are the sun and moon
of knowledge, pity two such noble lights
Should live obscured, here, here in a university,
Whose beams were fit t'illuminate any court
Of Christendom —

div.stage: Enter la Fiske, de Bube, and Pipeau.

sp.speaker: Fisk.
sp.l: Well look upon the astrolabe, you'll find it
For almucanturies at least.

sp.speaker: Bube.
sp.l: It is so.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Still of their learned stuff, they care for nothing.
But how to know, as negligent of their bodies
In diet or else, especially in their clothes
As if they had no change.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: They have so little,
As may well free 'em from the name of shifters.

sp.speaker: Fisk.
sp.l: Monsieur Latorch.

sp.speaker: Lator.
sp.l: How is it learned gentlemen,
With both your virtues.

sp.speaker: Bube.
sp.l: A most happy hour
When we see you sir.

sp.speaker: Lator.
sp.l: When you hear me then,
It will be happier; the Duke greets you both
Thus, and though you may touch no money father,
Yet you may take it.

sp.speaker: Ru●s
sp.l: 'Tis his highness' bounty,
But yet to me and those that have put off
The world superfluous.

sp.speaker: Fisk.
sp.l: We have heard of late his highness' good success.

sp.speaker: Bube.
sp.l: And gratulate it.

sp.speaker: Lator.
sp.l: Indeed he hath 'scaped a strange conspiracy,
Thanks to his stars, which stars he prays by me,
You would again consult and make a judgement
On what you lately erected for my love.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: O sir, we dare not.

sp.speaker: Fisk.
sp.l: For our lives.

sp.speaker: Bube.
sp.l: It is
The prince's scheme.

sp.speaker: Lator.
sp.l: T'incounter with that fear
Here's to assure you, his signet, write your names,
and be secured all three.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: We must entreat some time sir.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: I must then
Entreat, it be as present as you can.

sp.speaker: Fisk.
sp.l: Have you the scheme here?

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: I would you had sir
Another warrant.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: What would that do.

sp.speaker: Russ.
sp.l: Marry,
We have a doctor sir that in this business
Would not perform the second part.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Not
Him that you writ to me of?

sp.speaker: Rus.
sp.l: The very same.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: I should have made it sir my suit to see him,
Here is a warrant (Father), I conceived
That he had solely applied himself to magic.

sp.speaker: Rus.
sp.l: And to these studies too sir, in this field
He was imitated: but we shall hardly
Draw him from his chair.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Tell him he shall have gold.

sp.speaker: Fisk.
sp.l: O such a syllable would make him forswear
Ever to breathe in your sight.
Sir, he (If you do please to give any thing)
Must have't conveyed under a paper.

sp.speaker: Rus.
sp.l: Or left behind some book in his study.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Or in some old wall.

sp.speaker: Fisk.
sp.l: Where his familiars
May tell him of it, and that pleases him sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Or else I'll go and assay him.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Take gold with you.

sp.speaker: Rus.
sp.l: That will not be amiss, give it the boy sir,
He knows his holes, and how to bait his spirits.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: We must lay in several places sir.

sp.speaker: Rus.
sp.l: That's true,
That if one come not, the other may hit.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Well go then; is he so learned gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Fisk.
sp.l: The very top of our profession, mouth of the fates,
Pray heaven his spirits be in good humour to take,
They'll fling the gold about the house else.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Ay,
And beat the friar, if he go not well
Furnished with holy water.

sp.speaker: Fisk.
sp.l: Sir you must observe him.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Not cross him in a word: for then he's gone.

sp.speaker: Fisk.
sp.l: If he do come, which is a hazard yet,
Mass he's there, this is speed. Enter Norbret, Russee, Pipteau.

sp.speaker: Norb.
sp.l: Where is your scheme?
Let's see't; dispatch: nay fumbling now, who's this?

sp.speaker: Rus.
sp.l: Chief gentleman of the Duke's chamber doctor.

sp.speaker: Norb.
sp.l: O let him be, good even to him, he's a courtier,
I'll spare his compliment tell him: what's here?
The geniture nocturnal longitude
At twenty one degrees the latitude
At forty nine and ten minutes, how are the cardines?

sp.speaker: Fisk.
sp.l: Libra in twenty four, forty four minutes,
And Capricorn.

sp.speaker: Norb.
sp.l: I see't see the planets
Where, how they are disposed, the sun and Mercury●
Mars with the dragon's tail, the third house,
And pars fortuna in the imo coeli.
Then Jupiter in the twelve, the Cacadaemon.

sp.speaker: Bud.
sp.l: And Venus in the second, inferna porta.

sp.speaker: Norb.
sp.l: I see it, peace; then Saturn i'th fifth,
Luna ith' seventh, and much of Scorpio,
That Mars his gaudium rising in the ascendant,
That joint with Libra too, the house of Venus,
And imum coeli, Mars his exultation
Ith' seventh house, Aries being his natural house,
And where he is now seated: and all these show him
To be the almuter.

sp.speaker: Rus.
sp.l: Yes he's lord of the genitures,
Whether you examine it by Ptolemy's way,
Or Nasahales, Laell, or Alkindus.

sp.speaker: Fisk●
sp.l: No other planet hath so many dignities
either by himself, or in regard o'th cusps.

sp.speaker: Norb.
sp.l: Why hold your tongue then, if you know it; Venus
The lady of the horoscope, being Libra,
The other part Mars rules so that the geniture
Being nocturnal, luna is the highest,
None else being in sufficient dignity,
She being in Aries in the seventh house
Where Sol exalted is the alchocoden.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Yes for you see he hath his termine
In the degrees where she is found enjoys
By that six dignities.

sp.speaker: Fisk.
sp.l: Which are clearly more
Than any else that view her i'the scheme.

sp.speaker: Norb.
sp.l: Why I saw this, and could ha' told you too
That he beholds her with a trine aspect
Here out of Sagitary, almost partly,
And how that Mars out of the self same house,
(But another sign) here by a platique aspect
Looks at the hilage, with a quartile ruling
The house where the sun is; all this could I
Have told you, but that you will outrun me, and more
That this same quartile aspect to the lady of life,
Here the seventh promises some danger,
Cauda draconis being so near Mars,
And caput Algell in the house of death.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: How sir? I pray you clear that.

sp.speaker: Norb.
sp.l: What is the question first?

sp.speaker: Rus.
sp.l: Of the Duke's life, what dangers threaten him?

sp.speaker: Norb,
sp.l: Apparent and those sudden: when the Hyley,
Or alchocoden by direction come
To a quartile opposition of the place
Where Mars is in the geniture (Which is now
At hand) or else oppose to Mars himself, expect it.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: But they may be prevented.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Wisdom only,
That rules the stars may do it, for Mars being
Lord of the geniture in Capricorn,
is (If you mark it) now a sextile here
With Venus' lady of the horoscope,
So she being in her exilium, which is Scorpio
And Mars his gaudium; is o'er ruled by him.
And clear debillitated, five degrees
Beneath her ordinary power, so
That at the most she can but mitigate.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: You cannot name the persons brings this danger?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: No, that the stars tells not us, they name no man;
That's a work sir of another place.

sp.speaker: Rus.
sp.l: Tell him whom you suspect, and he'll guess shrewdly

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Sir, we do fear one Aubrey, if't 'twere he
I should be glad, for we should soon prevent him.

sp.speaker: Fisk.
sp.l: I know him, the Duke's kinsman, a tall man.
Lay hold on't Norbret.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Let me pause a little,
Is he not near of blood unto the Duke?

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Yes reverend sir.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Fart for your reverence,
Keep it till then, and somewhat high of stature?

sp.speaker: Lat
sp.l: He is so.

sp.speaker: Norb.
sp.l: How old is he?

sp.speaker: Fisk.
sp.l: About seven and fifty.

sp.speaker: Norb.
sp.l: His head and beard inclining to be grey?

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Right sir.

sp.speaker: Fisk.
sp.l: And fat.

sp.speaker: Norb.
sp.l: He's somewhat corpulent, is he not?

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: You speak the man sir?

sp.speaker: Norb.
sp.l: Well look to him, farewell. Exit Norb●

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: O it is Aubrey: gentlemen I pray you
Let me receive this under all your hands.

sp.speaker: Rus.
sp.l: Why he will show you him in his magic glass
If you entreat him; and but gratify
A spirit or two more.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: He shall eat gold
If he will have it, so you shall all, there's that
Amongst you first: let me have this to send.
The Duke in th' mean times and then what sights
You please to show I'll have you so rewarded
As never artists were: you shall to court
Along with me; and there not wait your fortunes.

sp.speaker: Bube.
sp.l: We have a pretty part on't in our pockets:
Boy we will all be new, you shall along too▪ .

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Good madam hear the suit that Edith urges
With such submiss beseeches, nor remain
So strictly bound to sorrow for your son,
That nothing else, though never so befitting,
Obtains your ears or observation

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: What would she say? I hear.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: My suit is madam,
That you would please to think as well of justice,
Due to your son's revenge, as of more wrong added
To both yourselves for it; in only grieving,
Th'undaunted power of princes should not be,
Confined in deedless cold calamity.
Anger (The twin of sorrow) in your wrongs,
Should not be smothered when his right of birth
Claims th'air as well, and force of coming forth.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Sorrow is due already, anger never
Should be conceived but where it may be born.
In some fact fit t'employ his active fame,
That else consumes who bears it, and abides
Like a false star that quenches as it glides.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: I have such means t'employ it as your wish
Can think no better, easier or securer
And such, as but for th'honours I intend
To your partakings I alone could end
But your parts in all dues to crying blood
For vengeance in the shedder, are much greater,
And therefore should work your hands to his slaughter,
For your consent, to which 'twere infinite wrong,
To your severe and most impartial justice,
To move you to forget so false a son,
As with a mother's duty made you curse him.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Edith he is forgotten for any son
Born of my mother, or to me a brother,
For should we still perform our rights to him,
We should partake his wrongs, and as foul be
In blood and damned parricide as he:
And therefore tell the happy means that heaven
Puts in thine hand, for all our longed for freedom,
From so abhorred and impious a monster.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Tell what she will I'll lend nor hand nor ear,
To whatsoever heaven puts in her power. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: How strange she is to what she chiefly wishes,
Sweet Edith, be not any thought the more
Discouraged in thy purpose, but assured
Her heart and prayers are thine: and that we two
Shall be enough to all we wish to do.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: Madam myself alone I make no doubt,
Will be afforded power enough from heaven
To end the murderer: all I wish of you,
Is but some richer ornaments and jewels,
Than I am able to provide myself,
To help out the defects of my poor beauty,
That yet have been enough as now they are,
To make his fancy mad with my desire,
But you know madam, women never can,
Be too fair to torment an amorous man;
And this man's torments I would heighten still,
Till at their highest he were fit to kill.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thou shalt have all my jewels and my mothers,
And thou shalt paint too, that his blood's desire,
May make him perish in a painted fire.
Hast thou been with him yet?

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: Been with him? no;
I set that hour back t'hast more his longing,
But I have promised to his instruments,
Th'admittance of a visit at our house,
Where yet I would receive him with all luster
My sorrow would give leave too, to remove
Suspicion of my purpose.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thou shalt have,
All I can add, sweet wench, in jewels, tires,
I'll be myself thy dresser; nor may I
Serve mine own love with an attracted husband,
More sweetly nor more amply than mayst thou,
Thy forward will with his bewitched affections:
Affects thou any personal aid of mine,
Mine noblest Edith?

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: Naught but your kind prayers,
For full effect and speed of my affair.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: They're thine (My Edith) as for me mine own,
For thou well knowest if blood shed of the best,
Should cool and be forgotten, who would fear
To shed blood still, or where (Alas) were then,
The endless love we owe to worthless men.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: Love of the worthiest ever bless your highness.

div.head: Actus. 5. Scaena. 1.
div.stage: Enter Rollo with a glass, Aubrey and servants.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: I never studied my glass till now,
'Tis exceeding well, now leave me cousin,
How takes your eye the object.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: I have learned
So much sir of the courtier, as to say
Your person does become your habit, but
Being called unto it by a noble war,
Would grace an armour better.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: You are still
For that great art, of which you are the master,
Yet I must tell you, that to th'encounters
We oft attempt, armed only thus we bring
As troubled blood, fears mixed with flattering hopes,
The danger in the service too as great,
As when we are to charge quite through and through
the body of an army.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: I'll not argue
How you may rank the dangers, but will die in't,
The ends which they arrive at, are as distant
In every circumstance, as far as honour
Is from shame and repentance.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: You are sour.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: I would speak my free thoughts yet not appear so,
Nor am I so ambitious of the title
Of one, that dares talk any thing that runs
Against the torrent of his own opinion,
That I affect to speak ought may offend you.
And therefore gracious sir, be pleased to think,
My manners or discretion have informed me,
That I was born in all good ends to serve you,
And not to check at what concerns me not,
I look not with sore eyes on your rich outside,
Nor wrack my thoughts to find out to what purpose
'Tis now employed; I wish it may be good,
And that I hope offends not. For a subject
Towards his prince in things indifferent,
To use the austereness of a censuring Cato,
Is arrogance not freedom.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: I commend
This temper in you, and will cherish it.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: They come from Rhone, Latorch employed you.
I must not now be troubled with a thought,
Of any new design, good Aubrey read them,
And as they shall direct you, use my power
Or to reply or execute.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: And captain bring a squadron of our guard,
To the house that late was Baldwins, and there wait me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: Some two hours hence.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: With my best care.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: Inspire me love, and be thy deity
or scorned or feared, as now thou favourest me. Exit Roll.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: My stay to do my duty, may be wrongs
Your lordship's privacy.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: Captain your love
Is ever welcome. I entreat your patience
While I peruse these.
How's this? A plot on me!

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What is contained
In the letters that I brought that thus transports him?

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: To be wrought on by rogues, and have my head
Brought to the axe by knaves that cheat for bread,
The creatures of a parasite, a slave,
I find you here Latorch, nor wonder at it,
But that this honest captain should be made
His instrument, afflicts me; I'll make trial,
Whether his will or weakness made him to it.
Captain you saw the Duke when he commanded
I should do what these letters did direct me,
And I presume you think I'll not neglect
For fear or favour, to remove all dangers,
How near soever that man can be to me,
From whom they should have birth.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It is confirmed.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: Nor would you captain I believe refuse,
Or for respect of thankfulness or hopes,
To use your sword with fullest confidence,
Where he shall bid you strike.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I never have done.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: Nor will I think.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I hope it is not questioned.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: The means to have it so is now proposed you,
Draw, so, 'tis well, and next; — cut off my head.
'Tis sir the Duke's pleasure,
My innocence hath made me dangerous
And I must be removed, and you the man
Must act his will.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I'll be a traitor first,
Before I serve it thus.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: It must be done,
And that you may not doubt it, there's your warrant,
But as you read, remember Hamond that
I never wronged one of your brave profession,
And though it be not manly, I must grieve
That man of whose love I was most ambitious,
Could find no object for his hate but me,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It is no time to talk now honoured sir,
Be pleased to hear thy servant, I am wronged
And cannot, being now to serve the Duke,
Stay to express the manner how, but
If I do not suddenly give you strong proofs,
Your life is dearer to me than my own,
May I live base and die, so sir your pardon. Exit. Ham.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I am both ways ruined, both ways marked for slaughter,
On every side about, behind, before me,
My certain fate is fixed, were I knave now
I could avoid this: had my actions,
But mere relations to their own ends, I could scape now:
Oh honesty, thou elder child of virtue,
Thou seed of heaven, why to acquire thy goodness,
Should malice and distrust stick thorns before us?
And make us swim unto thee hung with hazards.
But heaven is got by suffering, not disputing:
Say he know this before hand, where am I then?
Or say he do not know it, where's my loyalty?
I know his nature troubled as the sea,
And as the sea devouring, where he is vexed,
And I know princes are their own expounders,
Am I afraid of death? of dying nobly?
Of dying in my innocence uprightly?
Have I met death in all his forms and fears,
Now on the points of swords, now pitched on lances,
In fires, in storms of arrows, battles, breaches,
And shall I now shrink from him when he courts me?
Smiling and full of sanctity? I'll meet him,
My loyal hand and heart shall give this to him,
And though it bear, beyond what poets feign,
a punishment; duty shall meet that pain,
And my most constant heart to do him good,Enter mess
Shall check at neither pale affright nor blood.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: The Duchess presently would crave your presence.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: I come; and Aubrey now resolve to keep,
Thy honour living though thy body sleep. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Edith and a boy. A banquet set out.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: Now for a father's murder and the ruin,
All chastity shall suffer if he reign,
Thou blessed soul look down and steel thy daughter,
Look on the sacrifice she comes to send thee,
And through that bloody cloud behold my piety.
Take from my cold heart fear, from my sex pity,
And as I wipe these tears off, shed for thee,
So all remembrance may I lose of mercy,
Give me a woman's anger, bent to blood,
The wildness of the winds to drown his prayers,
Stormlike may my destruction fall upon him,
My rage like roving billows as they rise,
Poured on his soul to sink it; give me flattery,
(For yet my constant soul ne'er knew dissembling)
Flattery the food of fools, that I may rock him,
And lull him in the down of his desires,
That in the height of all his hopes and wishes,
His heaven forgotten, and all his lusts upon him,
My hand like thunder from a cloud may seize him,Enter Rollo.
I hear him come, go boy and entertain him.

lg.head: The song.
lg.l: Take o take those lips away,
That so sweetly were forsworn,
And those eyes like break of day,
Lights that do mislead the morn,
But my kisses bring again,
Seals of love though sealed in vain.
Hide o hide those hills of snow,
That thy frozen bosom bears,
on whose tops the pinks that grow,
Are yet of those that April wears,
But first set my poor heart free,
Bound in those icy chains by thee.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: What bright star taking beauties for me upon her,
In all the happy lustre of heaven's glory,
Has dropped down from the sky to comfort me?
Wonder of nature, let it not profane thee,
My rude hand touch thy beauty, nor this kiss,
The gentle sacrifice of love and service,
Be offered to the honour of thy sweetness.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: My gracious lord, no deity dwells here,
Nor nothing of that virtue but obedience,
The servant to your will affects no flattery.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: Can it be flattery to swear those eyes
Are love's eternal lamps, he fires all hearts with
That tongue the smart string to his bow; those sighs,
The deadly shafts he sends into our souls,
Oh look upon me with thy spring of beauty.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: Your grace is full of game.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: By heaven my Edith,
Thy mother fed on roses when she got thee.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: And thine on brambles, that hath pricked her heart out.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: The sweetness of th'arabian wind still blowing,
Upon the treasures of perfumes and spices,
In all their pride and pleasures call thee mistress.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: Will't please you sit sir.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: So you please sit by me.
Fair gentle maid, there is no speaking to thee,
The excellency that appears upon thee
Ties up my tongue, pray speak to me.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: Of what sir.

sp.speaker: Roll.
sp.l: Of any thing, and any thing is excellent,
Will you take my direction, speak of love then,
Speak of thy fair self Edith, and whilst thou speakst,
Let me thus languishing give up myself wench.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: Has a strange cunning tongue, why do you sigh sir,
how masterly he turns himself to catch me.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: The way to paradise (My gentle maid)
Is hard and crooked, scarce repentance finding
With all her holy helps the door to enter,
Give me thy hand, what dost thou feel?

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: Your tears sir,
You weep extremely: strengthen me now justice,
Why are these sorrow's sir?

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: Thou'lt never love me
If I should tell thee, and yet there is no way left
Ever to purchase this blessed paradise,
But swimming thither in these tears.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: I stagger.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: Are they not drops of blood?

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: They are for blood then,
For guiltless blood, and they must drop my Edith,
They must thus drop till I have drowned my mischiefs.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: If this be true I have no strength to touch him.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: Prithee look upon me, turn not from me,
Alas I do confess I'm made of mischief,
Begotten with all men's miseries upon me,
But see my sorrow's mind, and do not thou learn,
Whose only sweetest sacrifice is softness,
Whose true condition tenderness of nature.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: My anger melts, o I shall lose my justice.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: Do not thou learn to kill with cruelty,
(Those blessed eyes) as I have done with malice,
When thou hast wounded me to death with scorn,
As I deserve it lady for my true love
When thou hadst laden me with earth for ever.
Take heed my sorrows, and the stings I suffer,
Take heed my nightly dreams of death and horror
Pursue thee not, no time shall tell thy griefs then,
Nor shall an hour of joy add to thy beauties;
Look not upon me as I killed thy father,
As I was smeared in blood do thou not hate me,
But thus in whiteness of my washed repentance
in my heart's tears and truth of love to Edith,
In my fair life hereafter.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: He will fool me.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: O with thine angel eyes behold and bless me,
Of heaven we call for mercy, and obtain it,
To justice for our right on earth, and have it,
Of thee I beg for love, save me, and give it.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: Now heaven thy help, or I am gone for ever,
His tongue has turned me into melting pity.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Keep the door safe, and upon pain of death
Let no man enter till I give the word.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: We shall sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Here he is in all his pleasure.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: I have my wish.
How now, why dost thou stare so?

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: A help I hope.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: What dost thou here? who sent thee?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: My brother, and the base malicious office
Thou madest me do to Aubrey: pray.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: Pray?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Pray,
Pray, if thou canst pray, I shall kill thy soul else,
Pray suddenly.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: Thou canst not be so traitorous.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It is a justice: stay lady,
For I perceive your end; a woman's hand
Must not rob me of vengeance.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: 'Tis my glory.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: 'Tis mine, stay and share with me: by the gods Rollo
There is no way to save thy life.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.l: No?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No,
It is so monstrous no repentance cures it.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: Why then thou shalt kill her first, and what this blood
Will cast upon thy cursed head.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Poor guard sir.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Spare not brave captain.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.l: Fear or the devil ha' thee.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Such fear sir as you gave your honoured mother,
When your most virtuous brother shieldlike held her,
Such I'll give you; put her away.

sp.speaker: Rol.
sp.l: I will not,
I will not die so tamely.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Murderous villain,
Wilt thou draw seas of blood upon thee?

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: Fear not,
Kill him good captain anyway dispatch him,
My body's honoured with that sword that through me
Sends his black soul to hell, o but for one hand.

sp.speaker: Ham
sp.l: Shake him off bravely.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: He's too strong, strike him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O I am with you sir, now keep you from him,
What has he got a knife?

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: Look to him captain
For now he will be mischievous.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Do you smile sir?
Does it so tickle you, have at you once more.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: O bravely thrust, take heed he comes not in sir,
To him again, you give him too much respite.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: Yet wilt thou save my life, and I'll forgive thee,
And give thee all, all honours, all advancements,
Call thee my friend.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: Strike, strike and hear him not,
His tongue will tempt a saint.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: O for my soul's sake.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: Save nothing of him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Now for your farewell,
Are you so wary, take you that.

sp.speaker: Rollo.
sp.l: Thou that too.
O thou hast killed me basely, basely, basely. Dyes.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: The just reward of murder falls upon thee,
How do you sir, has he not hurt you?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No,
I feel not any thing,Sophia, Matilda, Aubrey, and lords at the door.

sp.speaker: Aub
sp.l: I charge ye let us pass.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Ye cannot yet sir.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: I'll make my way then.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: We are sworn to our captain,
And till he give the word. Enter Soph. Matil. Aub. lords and attendants.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Now let 'em in there.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: O there he lies, sorrow on sorrow seeks me,
Oh in his blood he lies.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: Had you spoke sooner this might have been
Prevented, take the Duchess,
And lead her off, this is no sight for her eyes.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O bravely done wench.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: There stands the noble doer.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: May honour ever seek thee for thy justice,
Oh 'twas a deed of high and brave adventure,
A justice even for heaven to envy at.
Farewell my sorrows, and my tears take truce,
My wishes are come round, o bloody brother,
Till this hour never beauteous; till thy life
Like a full sacrifice for all thy mischiefs
Flowed from thee in these rivers, never righteous,
Oh how mine eyes are quarried with their joys now,
My longing heart e'en leaping out for lightness,
But, die thy black sins with thee, I forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: Who did this deed?

sp.speaker: Ham●
sp.l: Ay, and I will answer it. Dyes.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: He faints, o that same cursed knife has killed him.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: He snatched it from my hand for whom I bore it,
And as they grappled?

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: Justice is ever equal.
Had it not been on him thou'dst died too honest.
Did you know of his death?

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: Yes, and rejoice in't.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: I am sorry for your youth then, for though the strictness
Of law shall not fall on you, that of life must presently;
Go, to a cloister presently carry her,
And there for ever lead your life in penitence.

sp.speaker: Edith.
sp.l: Best father to my soul, I give you thanks sir▪
and now my faint revenges have their ends,
My vows shall be my kin, my prayers my friends. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lator.
sp.l: Stay there, I'll step in and prepare the Duke.

sp.speaker: Norb.
sp.l: We shall have brave rewards.

sp.speaker: Fisk.
sp.l: That's without question.

sp.speaker: Lator.
sp.l: By this time where's my huffing friend lord Aubrey,
Where's that good gentleman — oh I could laugh now,
And burst myself with mere imagination,
A wise man and a valiant man, a just man
Should suffer himself to be juggled out of the world,
By a number of poor Gipsies: farewell swashbuckler,
For I know thy mouth's cold enough by this time,
A hundred on ye I can shave as neatly,
And ne'er draw blood in show: now shall my honour
My power and virtue walk alone; my pleasure
Observed by all, all knees bent to my worship,
All suit's to me, as saint of all their fortunes
Preferred and crowded too: what full place of credit
And what place now? your lordship? no 'tis common,
But that I'll think tomorrow on, now for my business.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: Who's there.

sp.speaker: Lator.
sp.l: Ha dead? my master dead? Aubrey alive too?

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Latorch sir.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: Seize his body.

sp.speaker: Lator.
sp.l: O my fortune,
My master dead?

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: And you within this half hour
Prepare yourself good devil, you must to it,
Millions of gold shall not redeem thy mischiefs,
Behold the justice of thy practice villain,
The mass of murders thou hast drawn upon us,
Behold thy doctrine, you look now for reward sir,
To be advanced i me sure for all your labours,
And you shall have it: make his gallows higher
By twenty foot at the least, and then advance him.

sp.speaker: Lator.
sp.l: Mercy, mercy, 'tis too late fool. Exit Lator.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: Such as you meant for me, away with him,
what peeping knaves are those, bring 'em in fellows;
Now, what are you?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Mathematicians,
And it like your lordship.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: And ye drew a figure.

sp.speaker: Fisk.
sp.l: We have drawn many.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: For the Duke I mean sir.
Latorche's knaves you are.

sp.speaker: Norb.
sp.l: We know the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: What did he promise ye.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: We are paid already.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: But I will see you better paid, go whip 'em.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: We do beseech your lordship, we were hired.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: I know you were and you shall have your hire,
Whip 'em extremely, whip that doctor there,
Till he record himself a rogue.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: I am one sir.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: Whip him for being one, and when they're whipped,
Lead 'em to the gallows to see their patron hanged;
Away with 'em.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Ah good my lord. Exeunt jugglers.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: Now to mine own right gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lord. 1.
sp.l: You have the next indeed, we all confess it,
And here stand ready to invest you with it.

sp.speaker: Lord. 2.
sp.l: Which to make stronger to you and the surer,
Than blood or mischief dare infringe again,
Behold this lady sir, this noble lady,
Full of that blood as you are, of that nearness,
How blessed would it be?

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: I apprehend ye,
And so the fair Matilda dare accept me,
Her ever constant servant.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: In all pureness,
In all humility of heart and service,
To the most noble Aubrey I submit me.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: Then this our first tie, now to our business.

sp.speaker: Lor. 1.
sp.l: We're ready all to put that honour on you.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.l: These sad rights must be done first. Take up the bodies,
This as he was a prince so princely funeral
shall wait upon him: on this honest captain
The decency of arms, a tear for him too.
Go sadly on, and as we view his blood,
May his example in our rule raise good. Exeunt.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
